org.lwjgl.openal

Class SOFTBufferSubData

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.lwjgl.openal.SOFTBufferSubData

  • public class SOFTBufferSubData
extends java.lang.Object
    Native bindings to the SOFT_buffer_sub_data extension.

    This extension allows an application to modify a section of buffered sample data while the buffer is in use.

      • alBufferSubDataSOFT

        public static void alBufferSubDataSOFT(int buffer,
                                       int format,
                                       java.nio.ByteBuffer data,
                                       int offset,
                                       int length)
        To update a section of buffered sample data, use the function alBufferSubDataSOFT.The named buffer may be attached to a source (either queued or by the BUFFER property), and the source does not need to be stopped, paused, or in an initial state to be modified.

        The offset value is the number of bytes from the start of the original data, and length is the number of bytes of the original data, to modify. If either offset or length are negative, or if the sum of offset and length reaches beyond the end of the buffer, an INVALID_VALUE error is generated. For compressed formats, length and offset must be block aligned. Complex compressed formats (such as those with no constant block alignment), may not be modified and will result in an INVALID_ENUM error.

        The specified format is the sample format of the passed data. The passed format must exactly match the format passed to BufferData, or an INVALID_ENUM error is generated.

        When modifying a playing source's buffer, an application must take care to not modify the section that is currently being played. The read-only source attributes:

        • BYTE_RW_OFFSETS_SOFT
        • SAMPLE_RW_OFFSETS_SOFT

        may be used to retrieve the read and write cursor offsets. Behavior is undefined if an attempt is made to modify buffer data between the read and write offsets.

        Parameters:
        buffer - ID of the buffer to modify
        format - sample format of the passed data
        data - existing buffer data to write to
        offset - number of bytes from the start of the original data
        length - number of bytes of the original data, to modify
